Award.AwardTitle: Planning: CE21 Maryland - Building Community and Knowledge to Increase Statewide Support for Computing Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Maryland, Baltimore County will gather data about the status of Computer Science education in Maryland high schools and build relationships among high school teachers, community college and university faculty, and state education administrators to facilitate and increase state-level support for lasting improvements to computing education. Despite the overall success of the K-12 education system in Maryland, opportunities to study computer science vary tremendously among the 24 school systems and approximately 200 high schools in the state. This disparity can be attributed to several factors, including the lack of a state-mandated computer science high school graduation requirement, the fact that there is no state-required teacher certification in the discipline, the absence of a standardized computer science curriculum, and barriers to entry for girls and underrepresented minorities.

In this CE21 Planning project, the interdisciplinary team at UMBC will focus on two main goals: (1) performing an assessment of the current state of high school computer science in each of the 24 Maryland school systems and (2) increasing knowledge about national issues associated with computer science education among high school and state administrators in Maryland, through state-wide summit meetings for teachers, administrators, and higher education faculty. The longer term objective of this work is to develop curriculum and teacher development programs that will improve the quality, breadth, and student diversity of computer science education in Maryland.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project had three major goals: (1) perform a baseline CS education assessment; (2) create knowledge and build community build; and (3) for the REU, analyze student persistence patterns at UMBC.

Goal 1: Develop a baseline assessment of the state of computer science opportunities and teacher preparation to teach computer science in Maryland high schools.

1. A comprehensive database of CS contacts in Maryland. Our contact database includes over 800 teachers, higher education faculty, administrators, and industry representatives. 

2. Data about Maryland high school courses and programs. We completed two "landscape surveys" of Maryland teachers to assess the state of CS education in Maryland. The results of the 2012 survey were published in a SIGCSE-13 article. The data and several crosstabulated analyses from both surveys are posted on the project website, and have been presented at several local and statewide events for high school teachers and administrators. We analyzed the data from the followup survey to create a comparison picture of the 2014 responses compared to the 2012 survey; a paper describing these results is in preparation. 

Goal 2: Increase knowledge about national issues associated with computer science education among high school and state administrators in Maryland. 

1. Advisory board minisummit. This event included advisory board members and a broader group of participants from multiple constituencies across the state. Fifty participants attended the minisummit, which was held on August 8, 2012. Additional advisory board meetings were held on November 2, 2012, and January 10, 2013. (The advisory board did not meet in 2014? it has been reconstituted as part of our ECEP minigrant for a meeting of a core group in September 2015 and an upcoming meeting of the full 25-member statewide steering committee in January 2016.)

2. Statewide CS education summit.  125 teachers, administrators, industry representatives, students, and college faculty attended this event at UMBC on May 17, 2013. The summit included welcome remarks by Dr. desJardins and UMBC Provost Philip Rous? a panel of undergraduate computing majors; sessions on CS-based Technology Education courses, the national landscape of CS education, the proposed AP CS Principles course, IT jobs in Maryland; a lunch panel on CS education efforts in other states; and a guided discussion of future directions. A statewide event on computing education in Maryland was organized by MSDE in May 2014, following on the success of our May 2013 event. Dr. desJardins was an invited panelist at this event, "Computer Science Initiative: Bits About Computer Science and Coding for the Future in Maryland" (November 3, 2014).

3. Training for teachers and students. The minisummit and summit provided professional development for participating high school teachers by informing them about the current state of CS education, curriculum, and national standards. The events have also provided opportunities for training of undergraduate and graduate students who have supported the events, developing organizational and leadership skills, knowledge about CS education, and data analysis experience.

4. Statewide reform. In part through the efforts of CE21-Maryland, in partnership with CSTA, code.org, and CRA, the State of Maryland passed legislation in 2014 that enables designated CS classes to count as a 4th mathematics credit towards high school graduation. In 2015, a directive by the ...

Goal 1: Develop a baseline assessment of the state of computer science opportunities and teacher preparation to teach computer science in Maryland high schools. 1. A comprehensive database of CS contacts in Maryland. Our contact database includes over 800 teachers, higher education faculty, administrators, and industry representatives. 2. Data about Maryland high school courses and programs. We completed two "landscape surveys" of Maryland teachers to assess the state of CS education in Maryland. The results of the 2012 survey were published in a SIGCSE-13 article. The data and several crosstabulated analyses from both surveys are posted on the project website, and have been presented at several local and statewide events for high school teachers and administrators. We analyzed the data from the followup survey to create a comparison picture of the 2014 responses compared to the 2012 survey; a paper describing these results is in preparation. Goal 2: Increase knowledge about national issues associated with computer science education among high school and state administrators in Maryland. 1. Advisory board minisummit. This event included advisory board members and a broader group of participants from multiple constituencies across the state. Fifty participants attended the minisummit, which was held on August 8, 2012. Additional advisory board meetings were held on November 2, 2012, and January 10, 2013. (The advisory board did not meet in 2014? it has been reconstituted as part of our ECEP minigrant for a meeting of a core group in September 2015 and an upcoming meeting of the full 25-member statewide steering committee in January 2016.) 2. Statewide CS education summit. 125 teachers, administrators, industry representatives, students, and college faculty attended this event at UMBC on May 17, 2013. The summit included welcome remarks by Dr. desJardins and UMBC Provost Philip Rous? a panel of undergraduate computing majors; sessions on CS-based Technology Education courses, the national landscape of CS education, the proposed AP CS Principles course, IT jobs in Maryland; a lunch panel on CS education efforts in other states; and a guided discussion of future directions. A statewide event on computing education in Maryland was organized by MSDE in May 2014, following on the success of our May 2013 event. Dr. desJardins was an invited panelist at this event, "Computer Science Initiative: Bits About Computer Science and Coding for the Future in Maryland" (November 3, 2014). 3. Training for teachers and students. The minisummit and summit provided professional development for participating high school teachers by informing them about the current state of CS education, curriculum, and national standards. The events have also provided opportunities for training of undergraduate and graduate students who have supported the events, developing organizational and leadership skills, knowledge about CS education, and data analysis experience. 4. Statewide reform. In part through the efforts of CE21-Maryland, in partnership with CSTA, code.org, and CRA, the State of Maryland passed legislation in 2014 that enables designated CS classes to count as a 4th mathematics credit towards high school graduation. In 2015, a directive by the Maryland State Department of Education was issued that permits school systems to count designated CS classes as satisfying the Technology Education graduation requirement. A Computer Science CTE completer sequence has been adopted and is being offered in a number of systems across the state. MSDE is currently working to adopt comprehensive K12 computing standards, and is actively pushing for widespread adoption of the AP CS Principles course, with our "CS Matters in Maryland" curriculum being treated as the "gold ...
